726262f-c.text:
Broadway (tracks thereon) east side, north from 51st Avenue (formerly Aaurice Avenue, also known as Cook Avenue) to Corona Avenue (formerly Union Avenue); showing at the corncr foreground, the C. Cook residence of 1873 (formcrly 56 Broadway). One Douglas wS the owner in 1891. John A. Rapelje's real estate office was located here in 1822. The houses beyond it occupy the site of the old Newtown House an old tire tavern. This site was eventually owned by the lst Reformed Church of Newtown. The Ne.town Hotel of later days stood on the opiuositc side of the street. Pn views 2,3, and 4 is seen the 1st Dutch Reforred Church of Newtowm. Te Dutch Ch rch Mas built on land donated April S, 1733. ine first edifice was erected in 1735 and was 7O60 ft. It Mas demolished on Sept. 4, 1831. Abraham Riker and his brother-in-law P. Rapelje gave the land for a church and burial around to the village of Newtown. The corner stone for the second edifice was laid on Sept. 16, 1831 by Elder Francis Durvea, and the edifice wad dedicated July 29th, 1832 by the Rev. Schoonaker D.D. Thhe bell used in this church was cast in Araterdam in 1792. The chapel adjoininm the chirch as erected in
1854.

726263f-a.text:
Broadway, south from 51st Avenue. On the extreme right is a portion of St. James Protestant Episcopal Chapel and beyond it is a local firehouse (building with bell tower). On the left is the cylindrical-turreted 110th Police Precinct and courthouse, formerly the Town Hall, built in 1891. The building with the watch tower was known as the Walter Building, havng been owned by one Schneller
1n 1891.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1922

726264f-a.text:
Broadway, at the S. E. corner of 51st Avenue, showing the Elmhurst branch of the Oueens Borough Public Library.
P. L. Sperr  June 7, 1927

725393f-a.text:
51st Avenue, east from and across Broadway. The fashionable house, on the left, was owned by one Douglas in 1891.
P. L. Sperr  July 2, 1935

726261f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, between 5lst and Justice Avenues,
viewing south toward the latter.
P. L. Sperr  July 2, 1935

726266f-b.text:
Broadway, at the S.W. corner of 51st Avenue, showing the original St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, built in 1735, and now (1941) known as the Parish Hall of St. James P.E. Church. Mr. Ogden states that the Newtown Historical Society, of whose council Dr. Paltsits,former head of the American History Division of the New York Public Library is a member, was organized in the
summer of 1941, in this building.
Views 1 and 2 show the rear of the place, on 51st Avenue, and view 3 the front, on Broadway. The new St. James Church is at the
N.E. corner of Broadway and Corona Avenue.
View 1:  Eugene L. Armbruster Collection March, 1925
View 2:  P. L. Sperr  July 2, 1935
View 3:  Gift of Beecher Ogden  July, 1941

726267f-a.text:
Broadway (trolley tracks thereon), at the S.W. corner of Fiftyfirst Ave., showing the original St. James Church (P.E.) now used
as a chapel.
About 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

726268f-b.text:
f5
Droadway at the S.W. corner of Maeoiot Avenue, showiug for views of the former St. Jares Epiucopal Church. It was erected ahout 1735. Pews were installed ir 1740. In 1760 the edifice was repaired and the 9teeple rebuilt. IIt was enlarged about 177O and again repaired about 1816. In 1922 it was pairted. The last services in this structure were held on July 16, 1848 when the new edifice was dedicated for service. Thia place has since been used as a chapel. The steeple was removed about 1900. A small buryirg ground is located in the rear of this chapel. The Rev. Evar Malhone Johnson, b 1792, was the rector from 1814-1827, when he removed to Srooklyn and there had erected the first St. John 's ChOrch in Brooklvn.
1622
Views 1 a nd 2
Views 3w4: May 1923.
Euoene L. Armbruter Collection

726269f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, between Fifty-first Ave. (right) and Queens Boulevard (left), showing a young ladies Seminary erected about 1812. It was subsequently in the possession of the Lawrence family. The
building was raned in 1932.
Arthur White.
